source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: An advanced Zircaloy cladding containing niobium has been developed and tested extensively both in long-term out-of-pile autoclave exposures and through high burnup irradiation in a pressurized water reactor (PwR) environment

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: Additional autoclave testing in LiOH solutions indicated a marked sensitivity of the Nb binaries to accelerated corrosion

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: in these solutions only the Sn-NbFe alloy was superior to Zircaloy-4

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: Experimental fuel assemblies with cladding of the advanced alloys were examined after one, three, and four cycles in the BR-3 reactor

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: Rod average burnups of up to 71 GWD/MTU were obtained with total residence times of up to 66 months

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_017_chunk5
evidence_span: The Sn-Nb-Fe alloy, called ZIRLO@, also displayed lower irradiation growth and creep than the others
